item.title: [Python] Othello game development made with Python
item.description: #Introduction I developed an Othello game using Python. Anyone can easily play github page https://github.com/chihina/othello-game-python Development environment python3.7.1 For other, please check requirement.txt on the following github page. https://github.com/chihina/othello-game-python Until the game starts First, execute git clone with the following command. git clone https://github.com/chihina/othello-game-python.git Next, install the libraries in a batch with the following command. pip -r install requirement.txt This concludes the environment construction. It’s easy. The following command will start the game.

item.title: [Python] GUI creation in python using tkinter part 1
item.description: ## Overview When executing a tool made with python, it is okay to call it from the command line if it is made by myself, but for tools used by people who are not related to development, it is better to be able to operate from the screen It is convenient. I investigated various ways to make an application with python and summarized the contents made. It’s still not very well made, so I plan to gradually adjust it.

item.title: [Python] Async/await with Kivy and tkinter
item.description: 2018 was a shock to me. I used to play around with [Kivy][kivy] of GUI Framekwork, but I found that using a generator can make ugly code full of callback functions surprisingly readable. Then, while trying various things, I became able to understand async/await asynchronous processing, which was a magic that was unfamiliar to me until then, and I was able to create a little asynchronous processing library. In this article The process until I realized the wonderfulness of the generator and the native coroutine born from it How to implement async/await with Kivy and tkinter using it I want to write it down.

item.title: [Python] I made a Christmas tree lighting game with Python
item.description: # Made *The video is double speed. I made a game in Python that connects electric paths and lights a Christmas tree light bulb. GUI uses Tkinter. The original story is a game that appeared on NORAD’s Santa tracking website a few years ago. Remembering that I loved it all the time, I decided to make it with Python, which I’ve been studying and can use nowadays. #Environment Python 3.

item.title: [Python] How to use tkinter in pyenv python
item.description: ## Issue The following error occurs when you do python -m tkinter or import tkinter with python installed by pyenv. When I read the article on the net, it said that it was cured by brew install tcl-tk, but it didn’t work. However, apparently it seems that the recently released pyenv v1.2.14 fixes the compatibility with tcl-tk, and GitHub issue I also wrote a solution, so I will share it.
